## Natural history notes

The Common Bogbuttons (Paepalanthus anceps) is a distinctive wildflower of wet savannas, bogs, and pine flatwoods in the southeastern United States. It produces slender stems topped with small, round, white flower heads that resemble tiny cotton balls. Blooming through the warmer months, it adds texture and color to nutrient-poor wetlands while supporting pollinators such as bees and flies. Its presence often signals a healthy, intact bog ecosystem.
